statement.tex: \text{What would the fourth term from the end}\\ \text{be if }\left(\frac{4x}{5}-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^9\text{ is expanded so that} \\ \text{terms with the highest power of x are}\\ \text{written first and those with lowest last?}

\\ \textbf{The m-th term.}\\ \text{Given that }T_1\text{ has higher powers of x than }T_2\\ \text{and }T_2\text{ has higher powers of x than }T_3\text{, will}\\ \text{the m-th term be given by the following?}

\\ \textbf{Closing the loop.}\\ \text{Is the following the value of the fourth term}\\ \text{from the end }(T_7)\text{ given that } \\ T_m = ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{10-m}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{m-1}?

reason.tex: (a+b)^n\text{ has }(n+1)\text{ terms. Similarly,} \\ \left(\frac{4x}{5}-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^9\text{has }N = 9+1 = 10\text{ terms.}\\ \therefore \text{ the fourth term from the end is }T_7\\ (T_{10}\to T_9\to T_8\to T_7).

\text{As }^nC_m = ^nC_{n-m},\text{ therefore }\left(\frac{4x}{5}-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^9\\ \begin{align} &= \overbrace{\sum_{m=1}^9\, ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{m-1}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{9-(m-1)}}^{\text{increasing powers of x}} \\ &=\overbrace{\sum_{m=1}^9\, ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{9-(m-1)}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{m-1}}^{\text{decreasing powers of x}} \end{align} \\ \underline{\text{Same expressions, written differently}}. \\ \text{But, we want to write it with decreasing}\\ \text{powers of x. Which means as}\\ \begin{align} &\sum_{m=1}^9\, ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{9-(m-1)}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{m-1} \\ &= \sum_{m=1}^9\, ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{10-m}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{m-1} \\ \implies T_m &= ^9C_{m-1} \left(\frac{4x}{5}\right)^{10-m}\cdot \left(-\frac{5}{2x}\right)^{m-1} \end{align}
